description: The Bachelor of Science in Business Administration is a professional degree providing the knowledge and skills necessary for successful careers in a variety of business fields. Students completing the degree will possess a strong foundation in all areas of business, including accounting, finance, management, and marketing. In addition, students will learn to apply quantitative and qualitative reasoning skills to complex business problems, integrate global and ethical considerations into their decision making, and effectively communicate business information. The College of Business is committed to providing students with high-quality instruction and relevant experiences in order to prepare them for leadership roles in business and society.
Accreditation status: AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business: Accredited.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Business Administration

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Humanities is an interdisciplinary liberal arts degree that provides students with a broad and deep understanding of human culture. Students develop skills in critical thinking, effective communication, and creative problem-solving by engaging with diverse perspectives from various fields, including philosophy, history, literature, art, and music. The program emphasizes analyzing and interpreting cultural artifacts, ideas, and traditions, fostering an appreciation for the complexities of human experience. Graduates are well-prepared for diverse career paths, including education, journalism, arts administration, non-profit work, and further graduate studies in humanities-related fields.

The Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Arts is offered with the following options: Interdisciplinary Studies, and Professional Studies. The Liberal Arts program provides students with a broad exposure to the humanities, social sciences, and natural sciences. Students develop critical thinking skills, effective communication, and a comprehensive understanding of diverse perspectives. The program emphasizes interdisciplinary study, encouraging students to explore connections across various fields of knowledge. Graduates are prepared for a wide range of career paths in fields requiring strong analytical and communication abilities, or for further graduate study in liberal arts or related disciplines. A Liberal Arts degree provides an excellent foundation for professional careers such as law, business, journalism, government, public service, and education. It also provides a foundation for graduate study in liberal arts or related disciplines. Liberal Arts majors acquire a broad base of knowledge, communication skills, critical thinking, problem-solving, and a global perspective applicable to a variety of careers.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Arts

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Studies program prepares students for a variety of careers and post-baccalaureate programs and offers two concentrations: General Concentration and Teacher Preparation Concentration. Students learn to critically analyze social, scientific, and aesthetic concepts from multiple disciplinary perspectives. They develop creative and analytical abilities, strong communication skills, and an understanding of our complex world necessary for active participation in the global community. The General Concentration provides a broad, interdisciplinary liberal arts degree. Graduates are well-prepared for entry-level positions in business, government, and non-profit organizations or for graduate studies in a variety of fields. The Teacher Preparation Concentration is designed for students who intend to pursue a Multiple Subject Teaching Credential. Students complete an approved program of courses that meets all subject matter requirements for the credential. This concentration also provides an excellent foundation for graduate studies in education and other related fields. Liberal Studies graduates who pursue a Multiple Subject Teaching Credential may enroll in Chico State's Master of Arts in Education-Curriculum and Instruction program. The Blended Program (Multiple Subject Credential) is designed to allow students to earn a Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Studies with the Teacher Preparation concentration and a Multiple Subject Credential at the same time.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Studies

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Multicultural and Gender Studies prepares students to understand and engage with diverse populations and to analyze the complex interactions between culture, power, and identity. This interdisciplinary major draws on a wide range of fields, including sociology, anthropology, history, literature, political science, and philosophy. Students will develop critical thinking skills, research abilities, and a nuanced understanding of social justice issues. The program emphasizes both theoretical analysis and practical applications, preparing graduates for a variety of careers in fields such as education, social work, public policy, non-profit organizations, human resources, and law. It also provides excellent preparation for graduate studies in a variety of disciplines.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Multicultural and Gender Studies

description:
The Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) degree is a post-licensure degree for registered nurses (RNs) who have an associate's degree or diploma in nursing and an unencumbered RN license. Students apply through Cal State Apply. Upon admission, students are then admitted to the online cohort.
The BSN program offers students the opportunity to advance their nursing career by building upon their prior knowledge and experience. Students will be provided with coursework that expands their understanding of evidence-based practice, community health, leadership, and professional development. The curriculum also prepares students for graduate study in nursing.
Our mission is to create an educational environment that fosters learning through evidence-based practice and scholarship. We prepare our graduates to be leaders in nursing, to be innovative and creative clinicians, and to be culturally sensitive, critically thinking, ethically competent professionals who contribute to the health and well-being of a diverse global community.
The curriculum meets the American Association of Colleges of Nursing (AACN) Essentials of Baccalaureate Education for Professional Nursing Practice and the California Board of Registered Nursing (BRN) standards. The program is offered in a fully online format.
Accreditation status: The RN-to-BSN program is fully approved by the California Board of Registered Nursing (BRN) and is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE).

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Religious Studies offers students the opportunity to critically examine the major religions of the world (Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Islam, Judaism), as well as indigenous and new religious movements. Through a variety of theoretical approaches and methods, students explore the diverse ways humans have organized their lives, understood their place in the universe, and developed moral guidelines for their communities. The Religious Studies major contributes to a well-rounded liberal arts education. It cultivates critical thinking, analytical skills, cultural literacy, and effective communication, all of which are highly valued in a wide variety of careers. The major is an excellent foundation for graduate study in Religious Studies, Law, Education, Public Policy, Counseling, Social Work, and Library Science, among other fields. Students with a Religious Studies degree pursue a variety of careers, including teaching (both K-12 and university), social work, community organizing, journalism, library science, non-profit administration, international relations, law, and business.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Religious Studies

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Social Science is an interdisciplinary major offered by the College of Behavioral and Social Sciences. The Social Science major provides a broad background in the various social science disciplines and focuses on the study of human society and social relationships. The program offers students the opportunity to integrate knowledge and skills across disciplines within the social sciences, including Anthropology, Economics, Geography and Environmental Planning, History, Political Science and Criminal Justice, Psychology, and Sociology. Our graduates are well-prepared for entry into a variety of career fields, as well as for graduate study in specific social science disciplines or professional fields.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Social Science

description: The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Sociology provides students with a scientific understanding of society, culture, and human interaction. Sociology majors learn to analyze social problems, social inequality, and social change using various theoretical perspectives and research methods. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, communication, and analytical skills, preparing students for diverse career paths in fields such as social services, criminal justice, public policy, research, and education. Graduates are well-prepared for entry-level positions in a wide range of organizations or for advanced graduate study in sociology or related fields. The program requires 120 units, including general education, major, minor (optional), and electives.

The 3D Digital Modeling and Environments Minor provides students an opportunity to develop foundational skills in creating digital 3D models and environments. Students will acquire theoretical and practical knowledge regarding how digital 3D is produced for a wide array of applications in media, including, but not limited to, video games, visual effects, and architectural visualization. The minor integrates the development of technical skills in 3D software with critical thinking regarding the role of digital 3D in society and culture. This minor is open to all majors. Interested students should contact the department office for advising.
Program name: Minor in 3D Digital Modeling and Environments

description: The accounting minor is designed for non-business majors who want to develop a basic understanding of accounting principles and practices. The minor provides students with the opportunity to gain foundational knowledge in financial accounting, managerial accounting, and other related areas. It is particularly useful for students in fields such as finance, economics, information systems, and general business administration who may benefit from a strong background in accounting. The curriculum is structured to complement various majors, enhancing students' marketability and analytical skills.

This minor is designed for students from a variety of academic disciplines who wish to broaden their knowledge in the area of adapted physical activity (APA). Adapted physical activity is defined as a service delivery profession and an academic field of study designed to address the unique needs of individuals with disabilities in diverse physical activity settings. Coursework in the minor includes introductory courses in APA, methods, assessment, and practicum experience working with individuals with disabilities. This minor is particularly suited for students majoring in Kinesiology, Exercise Physiology, Pre-Physical Therapy, Pre-Occupational Therapy, Pre-Athletic Training, Child Development, Psychology, Recreation, Social Work, and Special Education.

The Bachelor of Science in Advanced Manufacturing and Applied Robotics prepares graduates to be successful engineers and technical leaders in the growing high-tech manufacturing industry. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in manufacturing processes and automation, applied robotics, computer-aided design and manufacturing (CAD/CAM), product design and development, quality assurance, and manufacturing systems. Students gain hands-on experience in state-of-the-art labs with industrial robots, CNC machines, 3D printers, metrology equipment, and various manufacturing technologies. The program emphasizes problem-solving, critical thinking, teamwork, and communication skills, preparing students for diverse roles in sectors such as aerospace, automotive, medical devices, electronics, and consumer goods. Graduates are equipped to design, implement, and optimize manufacturing systems, integrate robotic solutions, manage production, and contribute to the development of next-generation products and processes.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Advanced Manufacturing and Applied Robotics

description: The Minor in Advanced Manufacturing is intended to provide students with foundational knowledge of current trends and best practices in advanced manufacturing processes. The program incorporates fundamental principles, materials, equipment, and processes that comprise this rapidly evolving field. Students will acquire the analytical and practical skills required to develop and implement advanced manufacturing solutions using relevant tools and technologies, including computer-aided design, rapid prototyping, and advanced robotics. The program is designed to prepare students for careers in advanced manufacturing and related fields and to provide them with the knowledge and skills necessary to pursue further education in the field.

The African American Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a critical understanding of the historical, social, political, economic, and cultural experiences of people of African descent. Students will analyze the causes and consequences of racial inequality and explore strategies for achieving social justice. This program enhances students’ critical thinking skills, broadens their cultural competencies, and prepares them to engage effectively in diverse communities and global contexts. It is a valuable complement to majors in the humanities, social sciences, education, business, and health sciences, among others.

The Minor in African Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a broad understanding of the historical and contemporary experiences of African peoples, both in Africa and in the Diaspora. Students interested in the minor should contact the program coordinator of the African Studies Program. The minor may be declared by any student. See the program coordinator for specific requirements regarding the minor.

Program Learning Outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this minor, students will be able to:
* Identify and describe major themes and issues in African history, cultures, politics, and/or societies.
* Identify and evaluate the ways in which African peoples (on the continent and in the diaspora) have expressed themselves, culturally and/or politically.
* Analyze the relationships between global issues and African peoples (on the continent and in the diaspora).

The Department of Agricultural Business provides students with the business skills and knowledge necessary to successfully manage a business in the diverse agricultural sector. The Agricultural Business curriculum provides students with a broad exposure to the agriculture industry while developing expertise in general business, economics, finance, and management. The program prepares students for careers in agriculture and related industries, including agricultural finance, marketing, sales, processing, distribution, and management. Graduates are employed by banks, government agencies, food processors, wholesalers, retailers, and entrepreneurial ventures. Many graduates also pursue graduate or law degrees.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Agricultural Business

description: The Minor in Agricultural Business is designed for students with majors outside of agricultural business who wish to gain an understanding of the business principles and applications in the food, fiber, and environmental industries. The minor introduces students to the core business principles, including accounting, finance, management, and marketing, and applies them within the context of agricultural and food systems. Students will gain an understanding of agricultural markets, economic principles, and policy issues relevant to the industry. This minor is particularly beneficial for students interested in careers in agricultural production, food processing, distribution, marketing, and related fields, or for those considering graduate studies in agricultural business or economics.

The Bachelor of Science degree in Agricultural Science is designed to prepare students for successful careers in agriculture and related fields, or for further graduate study. Students pursuing the BS in Agricultural Science may specialize in several options, or combinations of options, to accommodate their specific interests and career goals. Options provide specialized training in specific areas and are chosen in consultation with an advisor. Required core courses provide students with a strong foundational understanding of agricultural principles. Courses in the major promote critical thinking and problem-solving skills, and help students develop an appreciation for the social, economic, political, and environmental issues associated with agriculture.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Agricultural Science

description: The Agriculture Minor allows students to gain a foundation in agricultural studies while pursuing a major in another field. The minor requires 21 units and focuses on core agricultural principles and practices. Students will explore topics such as sustainable agriculture, agribusiness, crop science, and animal science, preparing them for careers in agriculture-related fields or further studies. This minor complements a wide range of majors, including business, environmental science, and public administration.

The Minor in Agriculture, Food, and the Environment (AFE) GE is designed to provide students with a broad understanding of the social, economic, political, and environmental issues related to agriculture and food systems. Students will explore topics such as sustainable agriculture, food policy, global food security, and the impact of agriculture on natural resources. The minor aims to enhance students' critical thinking skills and their ability to analyze complex challenges in the agriculture and food sectors. It also fulfills specific GE requirements. Students are encouraged to consult with an advisor to plan their coursework.
Program name: Minor in Agriculture, Food, and the Environment GE

description: The American Indian Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to provide students with an understanding of the historical and contemporary experiences of American Indian peoples. Drawing on courses from various departments including Anthropology, English, History, Multicultural and Gender Studies, Political Science, and Recreation, Hospitality, and Parks Management, the minor offers a broad and critical perspective on Indigenous cultures, societies, and sovereignty. Students will explore topics such as Indigenous history, cultural practices, political structures, social justice issues, and the impact of colonialism. The program emphasizes critical thinking, research skills, and an appreciation for cultural diversity, preparing students to engage thoughtfully with Indigenous communities and issues in their personal and professional lives.

The Animal Science program is designed for students seeking careers in production agriculture, equine, animal health, and allied industries involving food animals, companion animals, or horses. With an emphasis on hands-on learning, the program allows students to gain valuable experience at the Paul L. Byrne Agricultural Teaching and Research Center (farm) located just one mile from campus. Students learn to apply the principles of animal science to the management and production of livestock and companion animals. This major covers the fields of animal nutrition, genetics, breeding, physiology, health, behavior, and production systems. The curriculum is flexible and can be adapted to meet a wide variety of interests and career goals. Depending on their chosen option, graduates are prepared for careers such as:
*   Livestock, dairy, or horse farm managers
*   Poultry production managers
*   Feedlot managers
*   Nutritionists
*   Marketing and sales representatives for agricultural businesses
*   Animal health technicians (with further training or specialization)
*   Veterinary school (with further training or specialization)
*   Extension educators
*   Agricultural educators
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Animal Science

description: The Animal Science minor is designed for students who want to develop a basic knowledge of animal production and related agricultural issues. It is well-suited for students in other agricultural disciplines, or students in other fields such as Biology, Business, Environmental Science, or Health Science, who want to develop a fundamental understanding of animal agriculture. The minor provides foundational knowledge of animal science that would be beneficial to students interested in careers in animal agriculture, veterinary medicine, research, or related fields. The minor requires a minimum of 21 units.

Anthropology is the systematic comparative study of human biological and cultural diversity through space and time. Anthropologists address questions concerning the evolutionary history of the human species; the interplay of biology and culture in shaping human behavior; the origins and development of human societies and cultures; the dynamic diversity of modern human cultures; and the impact of human activity on the environment. At Chico State, the anthropology faculty have wide-ranging expertise across the four major subfields of the discipline: archaeology, cultural anthropology, biological anthropology, and linguistic anthropology. Students are provided with training in each of these subfields and are encouraged to explore their own interests and apply their anthropological knowledge in the field through internships, fieldwork opportunities, and community engagement. The Bachelor of Arts in Anthropology provides students with a broad and flexible education in the liberal arts tradition and prepares them for a wide variety of career opportunities, including further graduate study, teaching, business, government, forensics, public health, museum work, and cultural resource management. Students gain skills in critical thinking, cross-cultural understanding, communication, and social scientific research methods that are highly valued in today's globalized world.

The minor in anthropology provides students with an overview of the four subfields of anthropology: archaeology, biological anthropology, cultural anthropology, and linguistic anthropology. An anthropology minor can complement majors in disciplines such as health sciences, business, economics, foreign languages, and international relations.

The Applied Statistics minor provides students with the fundamental statistical knowledge and skills to collect, analyze, interpret, and present data in their own field of study. Students will gain a solid foundation in statistical theory and methods, including descriptive statistics, probability, inferential statistics, regression analysis, and data visualization. The minor emphasizes the practical application of statistical tools to real-world problems. The curriculum covers a range of statistical software and programming languages, empowering students to effectively handle and analyze diverse datasets. This minor is suitable for students from various disciplines who wish to enhance their quantitative skills and improve their ability to make data-driven decisions.

The Department of Art and Art History offers a Bachelor of Arts in Art, a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art, and a Minor in Art. Our programs provide students with a strong foundation in visual literacy, critical thinking, and creative practice, preparing them for a variety of careers in the arts and beyond. Students develop technical skills, theoretical knowledge, and an understanding of the historical and cultural contexts of art. They are encouraged to explore diverse mediums and approaches, fostering a unique artistic voice and perspective. Our faculty are dedicated artists, scholars, and educators who provide a supportive and challenging learning environment. We offer opportunities for internships, study abroad, and participation in exhibitions and community projects. Graduates are prepared for careers in fields such as art history, curatorial work, arts administration, gallery management, art education, graphic design, illustration, photography, web design, multimedia, animation, and studio art.

The Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) is a professional degree providing a concentrated and rigorous experience in the visual arts. The curriculum includes breadth in art history, aesthetic theory, and art criticism, as well as depth in studio practice, culminating in a senior exhibition. The BFA is designed for students seeking to pursue careers as professional artists or prepare for graduate study in art.
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art

description: The Art History minor provides students with the critical skills and knowledge of the visual arts necessary for careers in art-related fields (e.g., museum work, gallery work, historical preservation, publishing, arts administration, or other cultural institutions), or as preparation for graduate study in art history or related fields. The minor complements a variety of majors in the humanities, social sciences, and arts, particularly Studio Art. The courses offered introduce students to the diverse history of art and visual culture while honing their critical thinking, writing, and research skills.

The Minor in Art Studio offers students from all majors an opportunity to develop their artistic abilities through a diverse range of studio courses. Students will gain foundational knowledge and practical skills in various art media and techniques, fostering creative expression and critical thinking within the visual arts. The curriculum provides a flexible pathway for students to explore different studio disciplines such as drawing, painting, sculpture, ceramics, printmaking, and digital media, allowing them to tailor their artistic journey while complementing their primary field of study. Upon completion, students will have developed a portfolio of their work and a deeper understanding of artistic processes and concepts.

The Asian American Studies Minor offers students an opportunity to explore the historical, political, social, cultural, and economic experiences of Asian Americans in the United States. Students in the program develop critical thinking skills necessary to understand race, ethnicity, and gender in their local and global contexts. Through an interdisciplinary curriculum grounded in the humanities and social sciences, students will explore topics such as immigration, diaspora, identity, community formation, politics, arts and culture, and activism. The minor prepares students for careers in fields such as education, social work, public policy, law, health care, community organizing, journalism, and the arts, among others. It also provides a strong foundation for graduate study in Asian American Studies, Ethnic Studies, American Studies, and related fields.

The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Asian Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed for students interested in a comprehensive understanding of Asia. The program promotes analytical skills and critical thinking about a dynamic and strategically important part of the world, preparing students for careers in government, non-profits, international business, journalism, research, and education. It is also an excellent preparation for graduate studies in a variety of fields and disciplines. Asian Studies is an interdisciplinary field, drawing on courses in art, comparative religion, economics, geography, history, humanities, philosophy, political science, and modern languages. The program emphasizes global and cross-cultural awareness. The curriculum gives students an an opportunity to study in depth a particular region of Asia, such as China, Japan, Korea, or Southeast Asia, or a particular academic discipline. All students are required to take courses from at least three different disciplines and to complete two years of college-level study in an Asian language. The Asian Studies program is housed in the Department of Comparative Religion and Humanities. The Asian Studies program is highly flexible. It is designed to accommodate the needs of students with a variety of interests, whether they are focused on the region or on a particular discipline. Students are encouraged to study abroad in Asia, and course work completed abroad may be used to satisfy program requirements. Asian Studies majors are eligible for a variety of scholarships. The program works closely with the Asian Studies Association of California (ASAC), a professional organization devoted to the study of Asia. Students can attend the ASAC annual conference, participate in the undergraduate paper competition, and volunteer at the conference. These opportunities help students make contacts with faculty and professionals from around the world.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Asian Studies

description: The Minor in Asian Studies provides students with an interdisciplinary understanding of the diverse cultures and societies of Asia. Students explore the history, religions, philosophies, arts, literatures, politics, and economies of various Asian countries and regions. The minor aims to develop students' critical thinking, analytical, and cross-cultural communication skills, preparing them for careers in fields such as international business, government, education, and non-profit organizations, as well as for further graduate study in Asian Studies or related disciplines. This program is administered by the Department of Comparative Religion and Humanities.

The minor in astronomy is designed for students in any major who are interested in gaining a general knowledge of astronomy. The minor is appropriate for students who wish to satisfy their scientific curiosity regarding the nature of the cosmos, or for those considering a career in astronomy education. A minimum of 18 units is required for the minor. See the curriculum for specific information.

Biochemistry is the study of the chemistry of life. It provides the foundation for understanding all biological processes and for developing solutions to biological problems in medicine, agriculture, and industry. A major in biochemistry provides a strong foundation in chemistry and biology, as well as an introduction to related fields such as physics and mathematics. As a result, biochemistry majors develop excellent problem-solving skills, quantitative reasoning abilities, and communication skills applicable to a wide variety of career options. The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Biochemistry offers students a choice of two options: (1) an American Chemical Society (ACS) certified degree suitable for immediate entry into the chemical or biotechnology industry or graduate school in biochemistry, chemistry, or related fields; or (2) a non-certified pre-professional option for students interested in a career in medicine, dentistry, optometry, pharmacy, veterinary medicine, or other health sciences. Biochemistry is a joint program offered by the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry and the Department of Biological Sciences.

Biochemistry is an interdisciplinary program that focuses on the chemistry of biological systems. It covers the structure and function of biomolecules, metabolic pathways, and the molecular basis of biological processes. The minor in biochemistry is an excellent complement to majors in biology, chemistry, health sciences, or agriculture. It provides a strong foundation for students interested in careers in medicine, pharmacy, biotechnology, molecular biology, and other related fields. The minor also prepares students for graduate studies in biochemistry or related disciplines.

The Bachelor of Arts in Biological Sciences is designed for students seeking a broad education in biology with maximum flexibility to pursue interests in other fields. This degree is especially well-suited for students who plan to pursue K-12 teaching credentials in science, careers in science writing or illustration, and other interdisciplinary careers involving biology. The BA also can be used as preparation for health-related professional programs. Students who plan to pursue graduate studies in biology or careers as professional biologists are advised to pursue the Bachelor of Science degree.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Biological Sciences

description: The Biological Sciences program provides students with a strong foundation in a variety of biological disciplines (i.e., genetics, ecology, physiology, cell biology, evolution, etc.) that can be applied to a wide array of career options. The Bachelor of Science degree provides flexibility and depth of study through four options within the major: General Biological Sciences, Cellular and Molecular Biology, Ecology, Evolution, and Organismal Biology, and Plant Biology. Students are encouraged to enhance their academic program by engaging in activities such as independent research, internships, and student clubs related to their area of interest. These experiences allow students to gain valuable skills and make connections with faculty and community members.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Biological Sciences

description: The minor in Biological Sciences provides students with a broad exposure to the life sciences, complementing a major in another discipline. The minor requires a minimum of 21 units, 12 of which must be upper-division. At least six upper-division units must be taken in residence. All courses taken for the minor must be completed with a grade of C- or higher. See the Department of Biological Sciences website (www.csuchico.edu/biology) for recommended prerequisite coursework for upper-division classes in the minor.

The Biomedical Engineering Minor provides students with fundamental knowledge, skills, and applications related to the rapidly expanding field of biomedical engineering. Students will be exposed to a diverse set of topics that include human physiology, biomechanics, biomedical instrumentation, biomaterials, and medical imaging. This minor is particularly suited for students majoring in engineering, computer science, and the physical and biological sciences who are interested in pursuing careers or graduate studies in biomedical engineering. The Biomedical Engineering Minor is housed within the Department of Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering.

The Broadcasting minor focuses on the study of electronic media content production, distribution, and consumption. Students in the Broadcasting minor will critically analyze and understand the role of media in society, while developing practical skills in the areas of audio and video production, digital editing, and convergent media delivery platforms. Students will also gain an understanding of media law, ethics, and business practices as they relate to broadcasting and digital media production. The Broadcasting minor prepares students for careers in television, radio, online content creation, and other media-related fields, or for further graduate study in media and communication.

The Business Administration Minor provides a broad overview of business functions for students whose major field is outside of the College of Business. This minor helps students develop critical skills that will provide the fundamentals necessary to work in a business environment. All courses require a C- or higher to meet minor requirements.

Business Information Systems (BIS) is the field concerned with the collection, storage, analysis, design, and retrieval of information critical to the decision-making processes of a business enterprise. The Bachelor of Science in Business Information Systems provides students with the fundamental concepts and skills necessary to design, develop, and manage information systems critical to today's complex business environment. Graduates of the program are prepared for careers that involve developing, maintaining, implementing, and deploying information systems in organizations. Possible career paths include business analyst, systems analyst, database administrator, network administrator, IT consultant, web developer, data analyst, and project manager. The curriculum provides a strong background in business principles, database management, systems analysis and design, programming, networking, web development, and project management. Students also gain experience with current technologies and tools used in the industry.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Business Information Systems

description: The Minor in California Studies GE provides students with a broad interdisciplinary approach to understanding the physical, social, economic, cultural, and political conditions and history of California. The minor fulfills the Area F (Ethnic Studies) general education requirement. This minor will be of interest to students in a variety of fields who wish to develop an understanding of California issues or to explore careers in public policy, teaching, law, social work, journalism, or public and governmental affairs within California. Students pursuing the minor will learn to: *Analyze the social, political, economic, and cultural conditions of California within a historical context. *Identify the geographic, demographic, and environmental features of California. *Evaluate the diverse experiences of racial and ethnic groups within California. *Examine diverse cultural productions by communities and individuals within California. *Assess key issues and challenges facing California from a multi-disciplinary perspective.

The Minor in California: People, Places, and Cultures offers students an interdisciplinary approach to the study of California. It focuses on the physical and cultural landscapes, historical patterns, and contemporary issues within the state. This minor will be useful for any student who anticipates living and working in California. It is particularly relevant for students in fields such as recreation, tourism, journalism, environmental studies, education, political science, history, humanities, and social sciences. The minor offers students the opportunity to integrate knowledge from across the curriculum to better understand their home state.
Program name: Minor in California: People, Places, and Cultures

description: A minor in Career and Life Planning will provide you with the resources to help you create your own successful future. Students will develop skills to critically analyze their experiences, set goals, manage their academic and professional development, and create a comprehensive career and life plan. Students will learn how to identify personal values, interests, and skills that align with meaningful careers, and develop strategies for effective decision-making and problem-solving related to career and life transitions. This minor is open to all majors and will give you an advantage in today’s competitive job market.
Program name: Minor in Career and Life Planning

description: The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Chemistry program provides a core curriculum that develops fundamental knowledge in all branches of chemistry. The curriculum is designed to prepare students for careers that require a general background in chemistry such as chemical sales, chemical laboratory management, and science journalism. The BA degree also provides an excellent foundation for professional careers in the medical fields, including medicine, dentistry, pharmacy, physical therapy, and veterinary science. In addition, the BA program allows for exploration in other disciplines, making it a good choice for students interested in obtaining a minor in another field. The course of study includes hands-on experience in laboratory settings where students use instrumentation, such as infrared (IR), nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), and ultraviolet/visible (UV/Vis) spectrometers, and gas and high-performance liquid chromatographs (GC, HPLC). With the experience gained in the Chico State laboratories, students are prepared to work in industry, private and governmental laboratories, or to pursue graduate study.

The Bachelor of Science in Chemistry offers two options for students planning careers in chemistry or closely related fields. The General Chemistry option provides students with a broad background in all areas of chemistry and prepares them for further graduate study in all fields of chemistry, or for employment in research and development, quality control, technical sales, forensic science, and other areas of chemistry. The Biochemistry option prepares students for further graduate study in biochemistry, for professional schools (e.g., medicine, dentistry, pharmacy), or for employment in a wide range of biotechnology, pharmaceutical, and other medically related fields. All majors must complete a minimum of 120 units to graduate. For the B.S. in Chemistry, no more than 6 units of activity courses may be counted toward the 120 unit graduation requirement. The American Chemical Society (ACS) recognizes several of our programs. Students completing the ACS-certified programs will receive special recognition on their Chico State transcripts.
Accreditation status: American Chemical Society (ACS) recognizes several programs; specific options within the Bachelor of Science in Chemistry (General Chemistry and Biochemistry options) are ACS-Certified.

description: The Minor in Chemistry is intended for students in other fields who desire to strengthen their general knowledge of chemistry. This minor is particularly useful for students in fields such as biological sciences, nutrition, agriculture, physics, or physical education.

The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Child Development offers students the opportunity to learn about child development from a variety of theoretical perspectives. The program provides a broad foundation for understanding physical, social, emotional, and cognitive development from conception through adolescence in the context of family, culture, and society. Students acquire theoretical and practical knowledge in areas such as learning, perception, language, emotion, social relations, identity, and typical and atypical development. The program emphasizes the application of developmental knowledge in professional settings and offers students the opportunity to work directly with children and families in a variety of supervised field experiences. A degree in Child Development prepares students for careers in fields such as early childhood education, elementary teaching, youth program administration, child advocacy, and social services. In addition, the BA in Child Development provides an excellent foundation for graduate study in developmental psychology, education, social work, child life, and other related fields.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Child Development

description: The minor in Child Development is designed for students with majors in fields that complement and are complemented by the study of child development. The minor is suitable for students preparing for careers in education, nursing, recreation, social work, speech pathology, business, and other fields in which an understanding of children and families is essential. Students gain knowledge of child development from multiple perspectives, including developmental theory, cultural contexts, research, and application, and apply this knowledge to children, families, and communities. The minor supports students in developing critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills applicable to working with children across contexts.

The Minor in Cinema Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive knowledge of film history, theory, and aesthetics. Through a variety of courses from different disciplines (English, Comparative Religion and Humanities, Art, Communication Arts and Sciences, and Theatre), students will learn to analyze films critically and understand cinema in its cultural, historical, and aesthetic contexts. The minor complements a wide variety of majors, including those in the humanities, social sciences, and arts. The minor also provides students with a solid foundation for graduate work in cinema studies or related fields.

The Civil Engineering program combines a broad education in mathematics, physics, and chemistry with in-depth study in the major areas of civil engineering, including structural, geotechnical, water resources, environmental, and transportation engineering. Students learn to apply engineering principles to the design, construction, and maintenance of the infrastructure necessary for modern civilization. This includes water treatment plants, water delivery systems, wastewater collection and treatment facilities, hazardous waste remediation, air pollution control, building design, bridge design, dam design, highway design, traffic control systems, earth retaining structures, foundations, and site development.
Accreditation status: The Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering

description: The Minor in Classical Civilization offers students an opportunity to explore the Greco-Roman world and its legacy in various fields of knowledge and artistic expression. Students will gain an understanding of the Classical world through studies in ancient languages, literature, history, art, architecture, philosophy, and political institutions. Such interdisciplinary study broadens and deepens an appreciation of the foundations of Western culture while developing critical thinking and communication skills relevant to a wide range of academic and career goals.

The Coaching Minor is designed for students interested in coaching youth, high school, and/or collegiate athletics. This minor provides students with knowledge and skills to effectively coach various sports with a focus on sport psychology, exercise physiology, biomechanics, and motor learning. The minor provides foundational knowledge of coaching theory, injury prevention, sport safety, sport management, and interscholastic athletic administration. Students who successfully complete the minor will be prepared to coach in private and public athletic settings.

The Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) in Communication Design provides a professional degree for students interested in a career as designers. Communication design is a creative field that uses visual communication to convey messages and ideas. It combines design theory and practice with digital media and technology. Students develop skills in visual design, critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication to create effective and engaging design solutions across a range of applications, including branding, advertising, editorial design, web design, UI/UX, and motion graphics. The curriculum emphasizes both aesthetic sensibilities and strategic thinking, preparing graduates for professional practice in various industries and sectors.
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Communication Design

description: The Minor in Communication Design introduces students to the core concepts and practices of communication design. The curriculum focuses on visual problem solving, design thinking, and the creation of effective visual messages across various media. Students will develop foundational skills in areas such as typography, layout, branding, and digital media, preparing them for diverse roles in fields like advertising, marketing, web design, and user experience (UX) design. This minor complements a wide range of majors by providing essential visual communication competencies applicable in today's visually-driven world.

Communication sciences and disorders is the study of speech, language, swallowing, and hearing processes and their disorders. The program provides the foundational knowledge required for graduate study in speech-language pathology and audiology, as well as an understanding of normal and disordered communication across the lifespan.
The curriculum meets the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association (ASHA) undergraduate-level coursework requirements for students preparing to apply to graduate programs in speech-language pathology or audiology. A graduate degree is required for professional certification and state licensure in speech-language pathology and audiology.
The bachelor's degree in communication sciences and disorders is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to enter a graduate program in speech-language pathology or audiology. Students completing the degree will:
* Understand the basic processes of speech, language, swallowing, and hearing.
* Understand the nature of communication disorders.
* Learn how to apply basic principles of assessment and intervention for communication disorders.
* Learn how to identify and apply evidence-based practices in the field of communication sciences and disorders.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Communication Sciences and Disorders

description: The Department of Communication Arts and Sciences offers a major in Communication Studies leading to a Bachelor of Arts degree. The major focuses on understanding human communication processes in diverse contexts and cultures and preparing students to be effective and ethical communicators in a complex world. Students develop analytical, critical, and practical communication skills applicable to professional careers and advanced academic study. The curriculum provides a broad foundation in communication theory and research methods, with opportunities for students to explore specialized areas such as organizational communication, intercultural communication, rhetoric, and digital communication.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Communication Studies

description: The Communication Studies minor is an excellent complement to many majors across campus including business, journalism, political science, sociology, psychology, public health, and human resources. The minor introduces students to the study of human communication from various perspectives and in diverse contexts, and examines the role of communication in everyday life. Students completing the minor develop valuable skills in critical thinking, research, and written and oral communication. For more information, please visit the Department of Communication Studies website.

The minor in Comparative Religion provides students with an opportunity for interdisciplinary study in the academic field of religion. Students learn methods of critical inquiry for the study of religion and gain exposure to the diversity of religious beliefs, practices, and institutions across the world. The minor helps students develop skills in critical thinking, global awareness, and appreciation for diversity, which are valuable in a variety of fields and professions, including education, social work, law, and business.

The Bachelor of Science in Computer Animation and Game Development is an interdisciplinary program designed to prepare students for technical and creative careers in the digital entertainment industry. The program provides a broad foundation in computing, mathematics, and physics as well as specialized knowledge in computer graphics, animation, and game development. Students will develop skills in 3D modeling, texturing, rigging, animation, game design, programming, and interactive media development. The curriculum emphasizes hands-on projects and teamwork, fostering creativity, problem-solving, and collaboration. Graduates will be equipped to pursue roles such as technical artists, animators, game developers, graphics programmers, and simulation specialists in various sectors including entertainment, education, and industry.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Computer Animation and Game Development

description: The Computer Animation Minor is designed for students from a broad range of disciplines who wish to develop skills in the creation of 3D computer animation. Computer animation is a growing field that plays a vital role in entertainment, design, engineering, medicine, forensics, and scientific visualization. This minor provides a foundational understanding of the history, theory, and practice of computer animation. Students will develop skills in 3D modeling, texturing, rigging, animation, lighting, and rendering. The minor is a collaborative effort between the Department of Art and Art History, the Department of Computer Science, and the Department of Media Arts, Design, and Technology. This interdisciplinary minor allows students to apply computer animation skills to their major discipline. The minor is open to all students, regardless of their major, who have an interest in computer animation.

Computer engineers apply the principles of computing and engineering to the design, development, and implementation of computer systems and components. As a Computer Engineering student at Chico State, you will develop a deep understanding of both hardware and software, integrating knowledge from electrical engineering and computer science. You will learn to design, build, and program everything from microcontrollers to supercomputers, and from the internet of things (IoT) to artificial intelligence (AI) hardware accelerators. Graduates are prepared for careers in fields such as embedded systems, computer architecture, network systems, cyber-physical systems, and robotics.
Accreditation status: All engineering programs are accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering

description: The Minor in Computer Engineering provides students with an in-depth understanding of the hardware/software interface of computer systems. The courses expose students to design and analysis techniques used in computer hardware and software development. The minor is suitable for students in Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, and other related fields who want to supplement their major with an emphasis in computer engineering. Successful completion of the minor will be noted on the student's transcript.

The Bachelor of Science in Computer Information Systems is intended for students interested in careers as information systems professionals, data analysts, and related positions. Students learn how to analyze, design, develop, implement, and manage computer-based information systems. Graduates are prepared for careers in a wide range of organizations, including business, government, and non-profit entities. The program emphasizes both theoretical foundations and practical applications, equipping students with the skills needed to adapt to rapidly evolving technologies and solve complex real-world problems. The curriculum covers core areas such as programming, database management, networking, systems analysis and design, project management, and information security, alongside opportunities for specialization through elective courses and practical projects. Students are encouraged to participate in internships and research opportunities to gain hands-on experience and prepare for successful careers or further graduate studies.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Computer Information Systems

description:
About the Program: The Bachelor of Science in Computer Science provides students with the fundamental knowledge and skills needed for professional careers as computer scientists. Students gain a strong foundation in theory and practice that prepares them for a wide range of positions in industry, government, and education. The program emphasizes problem-solving, algorithm design, software development, and the underlying principles of computing systems. This program is accredited by the Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET.

Learning Outcomes:
Upon completion of the Bachelor of Science in Computer Science, students will be able to:
1. Analyze a complex computing problem and to apply principles of computing and other relevant disciplines to identify solutions.
2. Design, implement, and evaluate a computing-based solution to meet a given set of computing requirements in the context of the program’s discipline.
3. Communicate effectively in a variety of professional contexts.
4. Recognize professional responsibilities and make informed judgments in computing practice based on legal and ethical principles.
5. Function effectively as a member or leader of a team engaged in activities appropriate to the program’s discipline.
6. Apply computer science theory and software development fundamentals to produce computing-based solutions.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science

description: A minor in Computer Science allows students to build fundamental computer science knowledge and skills. It complements a variety of majors outside of computer science, such as those in the natural sciences, mathematics, business, engineering, and the arts. Students can tailor the minor to their interests through elective course options. The minor requires a minimum of 21 units.

Concrete Industry Management (CIM) is a four-year bachelor of science degree program with a business and technical focus dedicated to the concrete industry. The degree was developed in cooperation with leaders in the concrete industry to provide graduates with the expertise needed to manage increasingly complex concrete businesses. The CIM program is a comprehensive management degree that provides a broad understanding of the concrete industry and business principles. The CIM curriculum includes basic business courses in accounting, finance, management, and marketing with an emphasis on specific application to the concrete industry. Other technical courses include concrete materials, testing, production, design, and construction. This combination of business and technical skills will prepare graduates for management positions in the concrete industry. Students pursuing the BS in Concrete Industry Management will find challenging and rewarding careers in areas such as concrete materials, ready-mix production, concrete products, construction, consulting, equipment, and research and development.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Concrete Industry Management

description:
The Bachelor of Science in Construction Management is an accredited professional program for students who aspire to management careers in the construction industry. Construction managers supervise the daily operations of construction projects. They plan, coordinate, budget, and supervise construction projects from start to finish. They may specialize in residential, commercial, highway, or industrial construction.
The curriculum prepares students for careers as estimators, project schedulers, safety managers, project managers, and superintendents for general contractors or specialty contractors; and as facility managers, property developers, inspectors, and material and equipment sales representatives. Students completing the degree are prepared for entry-level professional positions in the construction industry or graduate study in construction-related fields. The program combines a broad general education with a major in construction management, covering construction graphics, building materials and methods, structures, surveying, mechanical and electrical systems, construction safety, construction law, estimating, scheduling, and project management.
The department offers numerous scholarships specifically for construction management students.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the American Council for Construction Education (ACCE).
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Construction Management

description: The minor in creative writing provides students with intensive training in the study and practice of writing poetry, fiction, and/or creative nonfiction, as well as an introduction to literary theory and analysis. The minor offers students the opportunity to hone their skills in literary interpretation and creative production, equipping them to become thoughtful and accomplished readers, writers, and critics. The minor is a valuable complement to any major for students who want to develop their writing and analytical skills, learn to articulate complex ideas, and explore their creative potential.

The Bachelor of Arts in Criminal Justice program provides students with a broad and systematic understanding of the criminal justice system and its related processes. The curriculum is designed to expose students to various theoretical perspectives, research methodologies, policy analyses, and practical applications relevant to the field. Students develop critical thinking skills, ethical reasoning, and an awareness of social justice issues within the context of crime and justice. The program prepares graduates for entry-level positions in law enforcement, corrections, courts, victim services, and related fields, as well as for advanced studies in graduate or law school.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Criminal Justice

description: The Criminal Justice Minor provides students with an understanding of criminal justice issues and a foundation in criminal justice scholarship. It is especially useful for students in the social sciences (e.g., psychology, sociology, political science, social work) who plan to work in justice-related professions or attend graduate school in criminal justice or criminology. The minor is also useful for students majoring in areas where justice studies might be related (e.g., computer science, recreation, health care management, public administration, business administration).

The Minor in Cybersecurity provides students with a foundational understanding of key concepts and skills necessary to protect information systems from cyber threats. Students completing the minor will be prepared to identify and analyze security vulnerabilities, implement security measures, respond to security incidents, and adhere to ethical and legal principles related to cybersecurity. The minor is suitable for students in various disciplines who want to enhance their career prospects with essential cybersecurity knowledge.

The Minor in Dance offers students opportunities to develop expertise in a breadth of dance forms including contemporary, hip hop, jazz, and ballet, as well as opportunities to develop skill and understanding in areas of dance production, choreography, improvisation, and pedagogy. In addition to enriching students’ cultural and artistic development, the minor in dance provides students with foundational skills and understanding that are often complementary to many majors including those in the performing arts, humanities, education, psychology, health and exercise science, and business. The minor in dance is housed within the Department of Theatre Arts.

Economics is the social science that studies how individuals, businesses, and governments make choices when faced with scarcity. The major provides a broad introduction to the field and trains students in analytical thinking and problem-solving. An economics degree provides a solid foundation for careers in business, finance, and government, and is excellent preparation for graduate studies in economics, business, public policy, and law. All economics majors complete core courses in microeconomics, macroeconomics, statistics, and econometrics. Students then choose additional courses based on their interests and career goals. The BA in Economics is offered in two concentrations: International Economics and Quantitative Economics. Students may also complete the general BA in Economics without pursuing one of these concentrations.

Economics is the study of how people make decisions when faced with scarcity. It involves understanding the behavior of individuals, firms, and governments in allocating resources, producing goods and services, and distributing income. The minor in economics offers students a strong foundation in economic theory, policy, and quantitative methods. Students will develop analytical and critical thinking skills, learn to interpret economic data, and understand the impact of economic policies on society. This minor complements a wide range of majors by providing valuable insights into economic principles relevant to business, public policy, social sciences, and humanities.

The Electrical Construction minor is an interdisciplinary program that provides students with a foundational understanding of electrical systems within the built environment. It covers topics such as electrical theory, wiring methods, power distribution, renewable energy systems, and relevant codes and standards. This minor is designed for students interested in careers related to electrical contracting, project management, and building systems design. It complements majors in Construction Management, Civil Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Sustainable Manufacturing, providing a specialized skill set valuable in the construction and engineering industries.

Electrical/Electronic Engineering is a broad field of study dealing with the design, development, and operation of a wide variety of systems and devices that use electricity as their source of energy or as a means of conveying information. Electrical/electronic engineers work in fields such as communications, power generation and distribution, control systems, solid-state electronics, computer design, and instrumentation. The Electrical/Electronic Engineering program offers two options: Electrical Engineering and Electronic Engineering. Students completing either option will be prepared for a variety of entry-level positions in the electrical/electronic engineering field and for graduate studies. The Electrical Engineering Option focuses on areas such as electric power and energy systems, electromagnetics, digital signal processing, control systems, and electronics. The Electronic Engineering Option emphasizes solid-state electronics, computer hardware design, digital signal processing, communications, and electronic instrumentation.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Electrical/Electronic Engineering

description: The Bachelor of Arts in English prepares students for careers that require strong skills in reading, writing, and critical thinking. English majors read a broad range of texts, including fiction, poetry, drama, and non-fiction, and explore the social, political, and historical contexts in which they were written. Students learn to analyze texts from multiple theoretical perspectives and write clearly, persuasively, and ethically. English majors also develop strong research, communication, and presentation skills. English students can also pursue an Honors in the Major, a departmental honors program, allowing them to engage in an intensive, two-semester research project. What Can I Do With a Degree in English? English majors develop a flexible skillset that is attractive to employers in a wide array of fields. Our graduates are well-prepared for jobs in education, publishing, journalism, technical and professional writing, communications, and library science. English majors are also competitive applicants for graduate programs in law, education, business, and, of course, English.

The minor in English offers students an opportunity to explore the rich field of literary and cultural studies while also building important writing and analytical skills relevant to many careers. The English Minor asks students to choose from a diverse range of courses, including literature, creative writing, linguistics, and rhetoric. Students who complete the minor will be prepared to critically analyze texts and cultural productions across time periods and genres, and to communicate effectively for a variety of audiences and purposes.

The Minor in Entrepreneurship and Small Business Management is designed to equip students with a robust understanding of entrepreneurial principles and practices. It caters to individuals across all majors who aspire to launch their own ventures, innovate within existing organizations, or pursue careers in small business management. Students will develop critical skills in opportunity recognition, business planning, resource acquisition, and venture creation and growth. The curriculum integrates theoretical knowledge with practical application through case studies, projects, and interactions with real-world entrepreneurs. Graduates of this minor will be prepared to identify and act on market opportunities, manage resources effectively, and navigate the challenges of the startup ecosystem or small business environment, making them valuable assets in any professional setting.
Program name: Minor in Entrepreneurship and Small Business Management

Concentration name: Ecology and Conservation, Environmental Policy and Management
description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Environmental Science program has two concentrations: Ecology and Conservation, and Environmental Policy and Management. Both concentrations provide students with strong interdisciplinary training grounded in scientific principles, preparing them for careers in environmental consulting, resource management, and state and federal agencies, and for graduate studies in environmental science and related fields. Students learn about the fundamental principles of ecological and physical sciences relevant to environmental issues and problem-solving, develop technical skills in data analysis and geospatial technologies, and gain a robust understanding of social, political, economic, and ethical dimensions of environmental problems. Students apply classroom knowledge to real-world problems through fieldwork and research opportunities. The Environmental Science program offers hands-on learning experiences, including field trips to diverse California ecosystems, research projects with faculty, and internships with local environmental organizations. The curriculum is designed to meet the growing demand for professionals who can address complex environmental challenges from a holistic perspective.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science

description: The Environmental Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a broad understanding of the causes, characteristics, and solutions to environmental problems. The minor requires a core of three courses (9 units) that provides students with a foundational knowledge of environmental concepts, methods, and issues. Additionally, students take 9 units of electives drawn from four interdisciplinary areas of study—natural sciences, social sciences, humanities, and environmental applications—that allow them to explore the field in more depth and from different disciplinary perspectives.

The Minor in Equity, Ethics, and Policy GE provides students with a general education pathway related to equity, ethics, and policy issues. Students will learn the analytical and critical thinking skills needed to understand and address pressing societal challenges involving social justice, fairness, and ethical decision-making. Students will study various perspectives on equity and justice, explore ethical frameworks, and analyze the policy-making processes that shape society. The minor encourages an interdisciplinary approach, drawing from fields such as humanities, social sciences, and public policy, to offer a comprehensive understanding of the complex interplay between equity, ethics, and policy.
Program name: Minor in Equity, Ethics, and Policy GE

description: The Ethics Minor provides students with an opportunity to engage in a structured course of study concerning ethical principles and their application within contemporary society. Through a variety of disciplinary perspectives, students will develop the capacity to critically analyze ethical arguments and make reasoned decisions in their personal, professional, and civic lives. The minor is interdisciplinary, drawing on courses from several departments across the university. It is designed to complement any major and is particularly beneficial for students interested in careers in law, medicine, public service, business, and any field requiring strong ethical reasoning skills.

The European Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of European society, culture, and history. Students electing to minor in European Studies will gain foundational knowledge of the political, economic, and social forces that have shaped Europe, as well as a critical understanding of the continent's diverse cultures and intellectual traditions. The program is an excellent complement to majors in the humanities, social sciences, and business, providing students with a global perspective and cross-cultural communication skills essential for success in today's interconnected world.

The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Exercise Physiology program provides students with the foundational knowledge and practical skills necessary for careers in various health and fitness settings. Students will learn about the physiological responses to exercise, biomechanics, motor control, exercise prescription, and nutrition. The curriculum emphasizes evidence-based practices and prepares students for advanced study in exercise science, allied health professions, or medical fields. Graduates are well-prepared for certifications from organizations such as the American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) and the National Strength and Conditioning Association (NSCA).
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Exercise Physiology

description: The Family Relations minor provides students with knowledge and skills relevant to family development and dynamics. Students examine the functions of the family within society, the impact of varying life events on individuals and families, and the issues relevant to different types of family relationships across the lifespan. The minor also prepares students for professions in human services related to families, children, and individuals, as well as for further graduate studies. The curriculum is flexible and allows students to tailor their coursework to align with specific interests or career goals. It also meets the coursework requirements for provisional certification as a Family Life Educator by the National Council on Family Relations (NCFR) when taken in conjunction with relevant coursework and/or experience.

A minor in Finance provides students with an understanding of financial markets and institutions, investments, and corporate finance. It complements a variety of majors by providing students with fundamental financial knowledge essential for personal and professional success. Students gain skills in financial analysis, decision-making, and risk management, preparing them for roles in various industries or for further study in finance or related fields.

The minor in food science provides students with knowledge and skills relevant to the food industry. Students gain an understanding of food chemistry, microbiology, engineering, processing, safety, and sensory evaluation. The minor prepares students for careers in food product development, quality assurance, regulatory affairs, and research, or for further study in food science and related fields.

The minor in Foodservice Administration provides the academic background for career preparation in institutional and commercial foodservice. The minor is offered through the Department of Nutrition and Food Sciences. The minor is a valuable supplement for students majoring in Business, Hospitality Management, Health Services Administration, or other areas where knowledge of foodservice administration is desired. Students completing the minor will have a strong foundation in food science, management principles, sanitation, and nutrition. The minor may not be taken by students majoring in Nutrition and Food Sciences.

The French Minor is an excellent option for any student looking to enrich their language skills and gain a deeper understanding of French and francophone cultures. Whether you're majoring in business, science, humanities, or arts, French can give you a competitive edge in today's globalized world. Learning French opens doors to careers in international relations, education, tourism, fashion, and many other fields.

The Gender and Sexuality Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a critical understanding of gender and sexuality as categories of analysis, social constructions, and lived experience. Students examine how gender and sexuality intersect with race, class, ethnicity, ability, and nationality to shape political, economic, social, and cultural institutions and practices. The minor helps students develop critical thinking and communication skills and gain knowledge and understanding that will benefit them in graduate school and in a wide range of careers.
Program name: Minor in Gender and Sexuality GE

Concentration name: Human-Environment Geography; Geographic Information Science; Planning and Development
description: The bachelor of arts in geography at Chico State is a human-environment program focused on understanding the reciprocal relationships between people and the environment. Students develop critical thinking, problem solving, data analysis, and communication skills applicable to a wide variety of professional career paths in the fields of environmental consulting, resource management, city/regional planning, geographic information science, and education. Geography students gain a robust understanding of the complexity of the world's most pressing human-environment issues and are prepared to become leaders in addressing them. Students gain competency in a number of critical skills including spatial analysis, cartography, remote sensing, and qualitative and quantitative social science research methods. Students can choose from three options, allowing them to specialize in Human-Environment Geography, Geographic Information Science, or Planning and Development.

The minor in Geography provides students with an introduction to key concepts and techniques in geography and spatial analysis. The program is designed to complement a wide range of majors by providing students with foundational knowledge in human, physical, and environmental geography as well as the technical skills to collect, analyze, and map spatial data. The minor offers students the opportunity to learn about geographic perspectives on social and environmental issues and to apply geographic information systems (GIS), remote sensing, and other geospatial technologies.

The Bachelor of Science in Geology offers an intensive curriculum for students planning careers as professional geologists in government agencies or private industry, or for students planning graduate study in geology, geophysics, or geological engineering.
