The curriculum includes courses in field geology, analytical methods in geology, earth materials, structural geology, stratigraphy and sedimentation, and paleontology. Students complete a common core of courses and then select from a variety of electives that allow them to tailor their degree to their specific interests and career goals.

The department operates its own instructional laboratories, with facilities for geochemical analysis, hydrologic and sedimentologic characterization, rock and mineral preparation, and geophysical studies. Extensive collections of rocks, minerals, and fossils are available for study. The department also maintains a field equipment inventory for student use in courses and research projects.

The Department of Geological and Environmental Sciences offers a minor in geology. The minor is a general geology program that provides students with a fundamental understanding of Earth processes and materials. Geology is the scientific study of the Earth. Geologists investigate the processes that shape our planet, its history, the materials that comprise it, and the living organisms that inhabit it. Geology is a quantitative and interdisciplinary science that uses techniques from chemistry, physics, and biology to solve complex problems relating to the Earth. The minor provides a basic understanding of geological principles which would be beneficial to students in a wide variety of disciplines including environmental science, agriculture, chemistry, physics, biology, and civil engineering.

The Minor in Geospatial Literacy is an interdisciplinary program designed to provide students with a foundational understanding of geospatial concepts, technologies, and their applications across various disciplines. Geospatial technology involves the use of geographic information systems (GIS), remote sensing, global positioning systems (GPS), and other related tools to collect, analyze, manage, and visualize spatial data. This minor aims to equip students with the essential knowledge and skills to effectively utilize geospatial information in their chosen fields of study and future careers. It emphasizes both theoretical understanding and practical application, preparing students to critically evaluate geospatial data, perform basic spatial analyses, and communicate geospatial findings. The curriculum is designed to be accessible to students from diverse academic backgrounds, making it a valuable addition to any major, from environmental science and urban planning to business, health, and social sciences.

The BA in German offers students the opportunity to acquire advanced proficiency in German language, literature, and culture; to develop the intercultural competencies that are essential in today’s global society; to learn critical analytical skills relevant to other fields; and to prepare for a variety of careers in fields such as business, education, government, and translation/interpretation, or for graduate studies. Through a combination of coursework in German and related areas, students develop a comprehensive understanding of the German-speaking world. The program also encourages students to study abroad in Germany or other German-speaking countries to further enhance their language skills and cultural understanding.

The German Minor provides students with proficiency in the German language and a deeper understanding of the cultures of German-speaking countries. This minor complements a wide variety of majors by adding an important international dimension, which is increasingly relevant in a globalized world. Students can enhance their knowledge of another culture and develop valuable intercultural communication skills by combining the study of German with their major of choice. Possible majors that can be enhanced by the German Minor include, but are not limited to, History, International Relations, Marketing, Business Administration, Political Science, English, Music, and Art. Furthermore, given that German is the most commonly spoken native language in Europe and Germany's economic importance, the German Minor can provide a competitive edge in many professional fields, including business, science, education, translation, and international relations. Furthermore, German language skills are extremely beneficial for advanced studies in a wide range of academic disciplines, including history, philosophy, and literary studies.

The Gerontology Minor offers an interdisciplinary approach to the study of aging. The minor addresses changes in physical, psychological, and social functioning in older adults within a socio-cultural and historical context. The Gerontology Minor helps prepare students to work with older adults in various settings and helps to develop a foundation for graduate study in gerontology or other fields. The minor is suitable for students in many majors including but not limited to health services, nursing, social work, psychology, recreation, child development, sociology, and liberal studies.

The Global Studies GE Minor offers a multidisciplinary approach to understanding the complex interconnections shaping our world. The minor helps students develop a global perspective, cross-cultural understanding, and an appreciation for global diversity. With a focus on critical thinking and ethical engagement, students explore global challenges like climate change, poverty, human rights, and migration, as well as the historical and contemporary forces that shape these issues. The minor complements any major by providing students with valuable skills and knowledge to navigate an increasingly interconnected world.

The Minor in Health and Wellness GE provides students with a broad understanding of the social, psychological, and biological factors that influence human health and well-being. This minor is designed to complement any major, offering students a foundation in health education, health promotion, and disease prevention. Students will explore topics such as nutrition, physical activity, stress management, mental health, and environmental health, preparing them to make informed decisions about their own health and to promote health within their communities and future professions.
Program name: Minor in Health and Wellness GE

description: The Bachelor of Science in Health Services Administration is a program designed to prepare students for careers in the growing and evolving health care industry. The program provides an interdisciplinary education in the foundational knowledge and skills required for entry- and mid-level health administration and management positions. Students in this program gain competencies in health care delivery systems, health law, health economics, financial management, health care operations, human resources management, strategic planning, health informatics, and leadership. The curriculum also addresses ethical issues, diversity, and cultural competence in health care. The program includes two emphases: Healthcare Management and Long-Term Care Management. Students must complete one of these emphases. The Healthcare Management emphasis provides students with skills in general health care administration. The Long-Term Care Management emphasis prepares students for careers in the long-term care industry with a focus on nursing facility administration, residential care for the elderly, and home and community-based services. All students in the program complete a required internship in an approved health care setting.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Health Services Administration

description: The Minor in Health Services Administration provides students with the opportunity to gain a foundation in health services administration. This Minor is designed for students who are interested in pursuing health-related careers and provides a broad understanding of the U.S. health care system, health care organizations, and the management of health care services. Students will learn about the challenges facing health care managers and how to address them effectively.

This minor is designed to provide students with a fundamental understanding of heavy construction. It is designed to prepare students for careers in the heavy construction industry where they will apply their knowledge and skills in planning, estimating, scheduling, and managing heavy construction projects. Students will develop skills in cost estimating, bidding, project planning, scheduling, site management, equipment selection, and safety in heavy construction environments. The minor provides a strong foundation for those interested in careers with heavy civil contractors, public works agencies, and consulting firms specializing in infrastructure projects.

The study of history provides students with critical skills vital for success in the twenty-first century. These skills include the ability to analyze complex issues; conduct research using a variety of sources; communicate effectively in written and oral forms; comprehend human societies and cultures in all their diversity; appreciate change over time; and understand the origins of current dilemmas and possible solutions to those dilemmas. The study of history is inherently interdisciplinary, often requiring students to apply methodologies from the social sciences, humanities, and sciences. It is also an ideal major for students interested in studying abroad, because it provides an excellent framework for understanding new cultures. A major in history is excellent preparation for a wide variety of career options, including secondary education, law school, library and archival work, museum studies, journalism, public service, and business.

The History Minor introduces students to the discipline of history. Students take a minimum of six units in lower-division and nine units in upper-division coursework. The minor can easily be combined with many majors offered at Chico State, including the Liberal Studies, Humanities, International Relations, Political Science, and Social Science majors. The minor will help students develop skills important in all disciplines, including critical thinking, research, and writing. A minor in history also prepares students for a variety of careers, including law, education, journalism, government, and business, or for graduate school.

The Humanities Minor invites students to explore the history of human creativity and cultural expression from antiquity to the present. The Humanities disciplines are devoted to the study of the human condition through critical engagement with literature, philosophy, history, religion, art, and music. The Humanities Minor will expose students to a breadth of study through required coursework that covers ancient and medieval, early modern, and modern periods. Students will deepen their knowledge through electives, choosing from a variety of courses offered by various departments across campus.

The minor in Innovation, Design, and the Arts (IDA) is an interdisciplinary program designed to support students in engaging with the world through a creative lens. This minor encourages students to innovate, design, and create in various contexts, providing them with critical skills to solve complex problems and contribute to a diverse and evolving society. Students will learn to apply design thinking principles, artistic expression, and innovative strategies to real-world challenges, preparing them for careers in fields that value creativity, problem-solving, and adaptability.
Program name: Minor in Innovation, Design, and the Arts GE

description: The Minor in International Business introduces students to the challenges and opportunities of business in a global environment. It provides students with a fundamental understanding of the global economy, international trade and finance, and the various cultures and business practices found around the world. The minor is designed for students from a wide variety of majors who desire to enhance their knowledge of international business. The minor is housed in the College of Business, which is accredited by AACSB International. In order to declare this minor, students must have a minimum GPA of 2.0.
Accreditation status: The College of Business, which houses the minor, is accredited by AACSB International.

description: The International Relations Minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of international affairs as well as the analytical tools to understand global processes. It is comprised of courses from a variety of disciplines including Political Science, Economics, Anthropology, Communication, Geography, History, and Foreign Languages. This minor is particularly suited for students majoring in the social sciences, humanities, or business who are interested in pursuing careers in international affairs, government, business, non-governmental organizations, or international education. In addition to a broad introduction to international relations, the minor also allows students to develop an area of specialization in either International Political Economy, Diplomacy and International Security, or Culture and Area Studies.

The Bachelor of Arts in Intersectional Chicanx/Latinx Studies (ICLS) is an interdisciplinary program that draws from the social sciences, humanities, and arts. It is designed to develop students’ critical understanding of Chicanx and Latinx experiences in the U.S. and transnational contexts, with an emphasis on the role of intersecting social identities and power relations. The program prepares students to analyze historical and contemporary issues facing Chicanx and Latinx communities through a social justice lens. Students will engage with diverse scholarly perspectives, theoretical frameworks, and research methodologies to explore topics such as race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, class, indigeneity, migration, colonialism, and cultural production. The ICLS curriculum fosters intellectual curiosity, critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and effective communication skills. Graduates will be equipped to pursue advanced studies in related fields or to enter professions that require strong analytical, research, and cross-cultural competencies, particularly in areas serving diverse communities, advocacy, education, public service, and the arts.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Intersectional Chicanx/Latinx Studies

description: The Intersectional Chicanx/Latinx Studies Minor provides an interdisciplinary and intersectional examination of the historical and contemporary experiences of Chicanx/Latinx peoples in the U.S. and its diasporas. Students in the minor will learn to critically analyze social constructions of race, ethnicity, indigeneity, gender, sexuality, class, and nationality and their relationship to identity formation, power, and resistance. Students will also gain a deeper understanding of the struggles for self-determination and social justice in Chicanx/Latinx communities, as well as the diverse cultural and political contributions of Chicanx/Latinx peoples to U.S. and global society. This minor complements a wide range of majors including social sciences, humanities, arts, and professional programs. Students completing the minor will be prepared for graduate studies and careers in fields such as education, social work, public administration, community organizing, law, healthcare, and journalism.

The Italian minor provides students with the linguistic and cultural competence needed to navigate a globalized world increasingly connected to the Italian-speaking world. The minor helps to foster linguistic proficiency, intercultural awareness, and critical thinking skills in students. It aims to develop in students a sophisticated understanding of Italian culture and language. This minor provides a foundation for students pursuing careers in a variety of fields, including education, international relations, journalism, translation and interpretation, public service, and business. It complements many majors, including but not limited to, art history, comparative literature, history, humanities, international relations, linguistics, political science, and women’s studies. Moreover, the Italian minor provides students with opportunities to study abroad. Students are strongly encouraged to contact the Department of Comparative Religion and Humanities to develop a course of study and discuss the benefits of studying abroad.

The Japanese minor is designed for students who wish to supplement their major by acquiring a basic knowledge of the Japanese language and culture. The minor offers courses in Japanese language at various levels, as well as courses in Japanese culture, literature, film, and society. The minor helps students develop linguistic proficiency, cross-cultural understanding, and critical thinking skills, preparing them for careers in fields such as international business, education, translation, and tourism, or for further academic study.

Concentration name: News Option, Public Relations Option, Digital Media Option
description: The Bachelor of Arts in Journalism prepares students to work as professionals in a wide variety of media and strategic communication careers. Through theoretical courses in journalism principles, media law, and ethics, and practical, hands-on learning experiences, students gain a comprehensive understanding of the profession. Students learn to research, report, write, edit, design, and produce content in a multiplatform environment and graduate with a professional portfolio of work. Journalism students learn how to think critically and analyze current events, preparing them for a range of professional and civic opportunities.

The minor in Journalism will provide students with both theoretical and practical experience in the journalism field. Students will acquire foundational knowledge in the practices and history of journalism, learn how to produce content for multiple media platforms, understand legal and ethical issues, and develop a portfolio of journalistic work. This minor complements a wide variety of majors and provides students with skills to effectively communicate with diverse audiences.

Concentration name: Exercise Physiology, Subject Matter Preparation Program in Physical Education
description: The Kinesiology program at Chico State focuses on the art and science of human movement. Our courses offer a challenging and rewarding academic experience with extensive opportunities for engaged learning through our state-of-the-art labs and hands-on teaching experience. The Kinesiology BA program offers an option in Exercise Physiology and a Subject Matter Preparation Program in Physical Education. We also offer a Kinesiology Minor. The Exercise Physiology option prepares students for careers in clinical, corporate, community, and university settings where physical activity and exercise are utilized to improve human health and performance. The Subject Matter Preparation Program in Physical Education prepares students for a career in teaching K-12 Physical Education. In both areas of study, students gain extensive experience in various aspects of physical activity, wellness, and sport.

Latin American Studies is an interdisciplinary program that draws on courses from departments across the university in the humanities, social sciences, and arts. The program is designed to give students a broad knowledge of Latin America and its peoples, including its history, societies, cultures, politics, and economics. Students gain a critical perspective of the region and develop skills in analysis, research, and communication appropriate for careers in a variety of fields, including education, government, business, journalism, and non-profit organizations. The program also provides excellent preparation for graduate studies in Latin American Studies or related disciplines.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Latin American Studies

description: The Latin American Studies minor provides an interdisciplinary approach to the study of Latin America, allowing students to develop expertise on the region from multiple perspectives. Students will choose from courses in diverse fields such as anthropology, economics, history, political science, religious studies, and Spanish. Coursework also fosters the development of critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills applicable to a wide array of career paths.

A minor in Linguistics consists of 21 units designed to provide the student with a general understanding of human language. This minor provides a useful supplement for students majoring in many fields, including Computer Science, English, International Relations, Journalism, Psychology, Sociology, and the various foreign languages. It offers students an opportunity to gain an appreciation of language as a human phenomenon and to broaden their understanding of communication as it relates to language.

The minor in Management Information Systems provides students with a fundamental understanding of how information systems are used in business. The curriculum is designed to give students a strong foundation in business intelligence, database management, and information systems design. This minor is suitable for students in any major interested in expanding their knowledge of information systems applications in the business world.
Accreditation status: The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.

description: The minor in management offers students an opportunity to develop essential management skills and knowledge. This minor is particularly useful for students in technical fields who wish to develop managerial and supervisory skills that are required for career advancement. The minor is also appropriate for students in other fields of study who wish to enhance their understanding of the management function in organizations.

The Managing Diversity in Organizations Minor provides students with the critical skills and knowledge needed to effectively manage diversity in the workplace. This minor is particularly valuable for students pursuing careers in human resources, management, marketing, and other fields where understanding and leveraging diversity is crucial for organizational success. Through a combination of coursework and experiential learning opportunities, students will develop a deep understanding of diversity concepts, learn to identify and address diversity-related challenges, and cultivate inclusive leadership practices.
Program name: Minor in Managing Diversity in Organizations

description: The Minor in Managing for Sustainability is an interdisciplinary program that integrates principles of sustainability into management practices. This minor is suitable for students in any major who are interested in understanding and applying sustainable practices in various organizational contexts. Students will gain knowledge in sustainable business models, environmental policy, social responsibility, and ethical decision-making, preparing them to lead and contribute to sustainable initiatives in their chosen careers.

The Minor in Marketing provides students with knowledge and skills for a career in marketing or for general business endeavors. Marketing is the process of planning and executing the conception, pricing, promotion, and distribution of ideas, goods, and services to create exchanges that satisfy individual and organizational objectives. Marketing involves studying consumer needs, developing products and services to meet those needs, pricing them appropriately, and promoting and distributing them effectively to target markets. Marketing is not only crucial for businesses but also for non-profit organizations and government agencies. This minor aims to equip students with a fundamental understanding of marketing principles and practices, preparing them for various roles in the dynamic world of marketing.

The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Mathematics is a rigorous degree designed for students with strong interest and aptitude in mathematics. This degree prepares students for graduate work in mathematics or mathematically intensive fields, as well as for careers in industry requiring advanced mathematical skills. Students completing the BS in Mathematics will be able to reason mathematically, construct proofs, and communicate mathematical ideas effectively. There are two options within the BS in Mathematics: General Mathematics and Foundational Mathematics.

The minor in Mathematics Education prepares students for teaching mathematics at the middle school and high school levels, either as a stand-alone minor or in conjunction with a Single Subject Credential in Mathematics. Students can pursue the minor in conjunction with their major degree program, such as mathematics, or as part of a post-baccalaureate credential program. The minor supports students in developing a deep understanding of middle school and high school mathematics, how to teach it, and how to support all students in learning mathematics, particularly for diverse student populations.

The minor in mathematics provides a strong mathematical background for students majoring in fields such as business, computer science, economics, engineering, natural sciences, or social sciences. The minor also benefits students who plan to pursue graduate work in these or other fields requiring a solid understanding of mathematics.

Mechanical Engineering is a broad field, covering topics such as product design, manufacturing, quality control, instrumentation, energy systems, power generation, air conditioning, and aerospace. Because of the breadth of the discipline, mechanical engineers find employment in almost every branch of industry, including aerospace, manufacturing, construction, consulting, energy, and transportation, as well as in all levels of government service and education. The department offers a Bachelor of Science degree in Mechanical Engineering. The Mechanical Engineering program provides a strong foundation in the fundamentals of engineering science, mathematics, and physical science that prepares students to understand and solve engineering problems across a broad spectrum of industries. Students develop practical skills through hands-on labs and team-based design projects, which culminate in a capstone senior design project. The program is designed to prepare students for entry-level positions in industry or for graduate study.
Accreditation status: The Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering

description: Mechatronic engineering is a dynamic interdisciplinary field that integrates mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, computer science, and control engineering. Mechatronic engineers design, develop, and test automated equipment, smart products, and manufacturing processes. They apply engineering principles to the design of systems such that the final product is a combination of mechanical structures, electronic hardware, and computer software. Areas of application include intelligent systems for precision agriculture, advanced manufacturing, robotics, automation, autonomous vehicles, smart medical devices, and rehabilitation systems. The Mechatronic Engineering program provides students with hands-on experience in the design, construction, and testing of complex robotic and automation systems. The goal of the program is to prepare students for successful careers in industry, or to continue on to graduate studies in engineering. The program requires 120 units.
Accreditation status: The Mechatronic Engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Mechatronic Engineering

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Media Arts prepares students for careers in the rapidly changing fields of electronic media, digital culture, and converging technologies, as well as for graduate study in related fields. The curriculum focuses on theory and practice in video production, sound production, interactive media, media analysis, criticism, and media writing. Students in the Media Arts program develop critical thinking skills, analytical skills, and technical proficiency in creating and analyzing contemporary media forms, content, and industries. Through a core curriculum, students gain a strong theoretical and historical foundation in media arts, as well as hands-on experience in media production. Students also choose a concentration that allows them to specialize in an area of interest.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Media Arts

description: The Minor in Medieval and Renaissance Studies offers students an interdisciplinary exploration of the cultures of Western Europe and the Mediterranean from approximately 400 CE to 1600 CE. Students examine the historical, literary, religious, and artistic developments of the period from multiple perspectives, drawing on courses in Art History, Comparative Religion, English, History, Humanities, Languages, Literatures, and Cultures, Music, Philosophy, and Political Science. The minor is suitable for students in any major.
Program name: Minor in Medieval and Renaissance Studies

description: The Department of Biological Sciences offers a Bachelor of Science in Microbiology. The program provides comprehensive training in microbial diversity, physiology, genetics, immunology, and pathogenesis. Students will gain theoretical knowledge and practical laboratory skills essential for understanding microorganisms and their impact on various aspects of life, including health, environment, and industry. Graduates are prepared for diverse careers in research, healthcare, biotechnology, public health, and further graduate studies in microbiology or related fields. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, experimental design, data analysis, and scientific communication.

The minor in Middle Eastern Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a broad understanding of the histories, cultures, politics, and geographies of the Middle East region. Students will study the region from a variety of disciplinary perspectives, including anthropology, comparative religion, English, history, political science, and philosophy. The program is designed to complement any major, and students will gain knowledge and skills relevant to a wide variety of career options, including government service, journalism, international business, and academic research.

The Minor in Modern Jewish & Israel Studies explores the cultural, historical, political, and religious heritage of the Jewish people from the 18th century to the present. With a focus on the modern period, the minor examines the diversity of Jewish experience in the diaspora and in Israel.
Program name: Minor in Modern Jewish and Israel Studies

description: The minor in Multicultural Studies is designed to provide students with the opportunity to explore the historical, sociological, psychological, and cultural dimensions of multicultural experiences in the United States. Students will critically examine concepts of race, ethnicity, gender, class, and sexual orientation within a multidisciplinary framework, fostering a deeper understanding of diversity and social justice issues. The curriculum emphasizes the development of analytical skills, cross-cultural communication, and an appreciation for various cultural perspectives. This minor complements a wide range of majors by enhancing students' ability to engage effectively in diverse communities and workplaces. Students completing this minor will be better prepared to address the challenges and opportunities presented by an increasingly multicultural society.

The Bachelor of Arts in Music provides students with an in-depth study of music within a broad liberal arts curriculum. Students gain knowledge and experience in music history, theory, and performance, with opportunities for specialization in various musical areas. The program emphasizes critical thinking, creativity, and cultural understanding through music. Graduates are prepared for careers in music education, performance, music industry, or for further graduate study.

The Bachelor of Arts in Music Industry and Technology provides students with professional skills for a successful career in today’s rapidly evolving music and entertainment industries. The curriculum focuses on preparing students to work in various fields, including sound recording, live sound production, music business, songwriting, and performance. Students will gain a strong foundation in music theory, history, and musicianship, along with practical training in audio engineering, music production, and business practices. The program emphasizes hands-on experience, critical thinking, and creative problem-solving, preparing graduates to adapt to the dynamic demands of the music industry. Our goal is to empower students to pursue their passions and make a meaningful impact in the world of music.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Music Industry and Technology

description: The minor in Music is designed for students whose majors are outside the Department of Music and who wish to increase their knowledge and skills in music. The minor is not available to Music majors. Students who complete the minor will gain a comprehensive foundation in music history, theory, and performance. The minor offers flexibility, allowing students to select courses that align with their interests while exploring a variety of musical concepts and styles.

The Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) in Musical Theatre is an intensive, pre-professional training program for students interested in pursuing careers as musical theatre performers. Students receive comprehensive training in acting, voice, and dance, along with a strong academic foundation in theatre history, theory, and literature. The program emphasizes practical experience through rigorous production opportunities in musical theatre, plays, and other performance events. Students develop a broad range of skills applicable to stage, film, and television, preparing them for the demands of the professional entertainment industry. The curriculum is designed to foster artistic growth, critical thinking, and collaborative skills essential for success in musical theatre.
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Musical Theatre

description: The Bachelor of Science in Natural Sciences is an interdisciplinary degree program that offers students a broad, foundational education in the sciences. The curriculum provides breadth in the biological and physical sciences, and depth in selected scientific areas. The degree program is a flexible major for students who desire a science education and career, but whose interests do not align with a single science discipline. This interdisciplinary degree allows students to acquire a broad scientific education with sufficient depth to enter science-related professions or graduate programs. Students completing the degree may pursue a variety of careers in science, education, science writing, policy, and law. Additionally, the degree is excellent preparation for some health-related graduate programs. The program offers two concentrations: a General Concentration and a Science Education Concentration.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Natural Sciences

description: The Bachelor of Science in Nursing program at Chico State prepares students for professional nursing practice across diverse healthcare settings, offering a balance of general education, scientific knowledge, and professional nursing concepts. Students gain hands-on experience through clinical rotations in various healthcare facilities, including hospitals, community clinics, and public health agencies, working with diverse patient populations under the supervision of experienced faculty. Graduates are eligible to take the National Council Licensure Examination (NCLEX-RN) and pursue careers as registered nurses. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, evidence-based practice, patient-centered care, teamwork, and leadership, fostering graduates who are skilled clinicians, effective communicators, and compassionate advocates for health.
Accreditation status: The Bachelor of Science in Nursing program is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE) and approved by the California Board of Registered Nursing (BRN).

description:
The Bachelor of Science in Nutrition and Food Sciences prepares students for a variety of careers in nutrition and food science. Students develop knowledge and skills in areas such as food science, human nutrition, medical nutrition therapy, community nutrition, food safety, and foodservice management. This degree also provides a strong foundation for advanced study in nutrition, food science, and health-related professions. The program offers three options for specialized study, allowing students to tailor their education to specific career goals: Dietetics, Food Science, and General Nutrition.
Upon completion of this program, students will be able to:
*   Apply scientific principles to understand the composition, properties, and processing of food.
*   Analyze the role of nutrients in human health and disease prevention.
*   Evaluate dietary intake and develop evidence-based nutrition interventions.
*   Apply principles of food safety and quality assurance in various settings.
*   Communicate effectively about nutrition and food science to diverse audiences.
*   Demonstrate ethical and professional conduct in nutrition and food science practice.
Accreditation status: The Dietetics option within the Bachelor of Science in Nutrition and Food Sciences program is accredited by the Accreditation Council for Education in Nutrition and Dietetics (ACEND) of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, 120 South Riverside Plaza, Suite 2190, Chicago, IL 60606-6995, (312) 899-0040 ext. 5400.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Nutrition and Food Sciences

description: This minor is designed for students interested in developing an understanding of how nutrition impacts physical activity, sport, and overall human performance. This minor complements a wide variety of majors by providing fundamental knowledge and skills in topics such as sports nutrition, exercise physiology, human metabolism, and assessment of nutritional status for active individuals. Students completing this minor will gain valuable knowledge and skills to enhance their future careers in fields such as health and fitness, athletic training, physical therapy, coaching, strength and conditioning, and other health-related professions.
Program name: Minor in Nutrition for Human Performance

description: The Nutrition minor is designed for students in other majors interested in increasing their knowledge of basic nutrition and dietetics. The program will provide an overview of the role nutrition plays in health and disease prevention, wellness, and promotion across the lifespan. The minor also provides a basic understanding of nutrition care and education as it applies to individuals and communities. The minor supports careers in nursing, exercise physiology, community health, and food and business, among others.

The Operations and Supply Chain Management minor is an excellent addition to any business or non-business major. In today's global economy, businesses strive to increase efficiency and maximize customer value. The minor will help students understand how organizations manage resources, processes, and relationships to achieve their strategic goals. Students will gain knowledge of the key functions in operations and supply chain management, including forecasting, inventory management, production planning, quality management, logistics, and supply chain design. This minor provides an opportunity to develop analytical and problem-solving skills highly valued by employers. It will prepare students for careers in diverse industries such as manufacturing, healthcare, logistics, and retail. Students will also learn about the latest trends and technologies in the field, such as automation, artificial intelligence, and sustainable supply chains. Whether you aspire to work in operations, procurement, logistics, or consulting, this minor will provide you with a solid foundation to succeed in the dynamic world of operations and supply chain management.
Program name: Minor in Operations and Supply Chain Management

description: The Philosophy and Law minor provides an opportunity for students to think philosophically about the nature of law and its relation to justice, morality, and social policy. The minor is suitable for any student with an interest in law, including those considering a career in the legal professions. Students will learn the philosophical foundations of legal systems, explore the ethical dimensions of legal practice and policy, and develop critical thinking skills essential for analyzing complex legal and ethical issues. This minor complements a wide range of majors including Political Science, Criminal Justice, Business Administration, Communication, and many others. Students must earn a grade of C- or higher in all courses counted toward the minor.

Philosophy is about understanding who we are and what kind of lives we ought to lead, what we know and how we know it, what beauty is and how to appreciate it, what justice is and how to achieve it, and what our place is in the universe. In the study of philosophy, you will critically examine some of the most fundamental questions human beings have ever asked. You will also learn to develop rigorous arguments, write clear and compelling prose, and analyze complex issues. You will be trained in careful thinking about perennial and contemporary problems related to ethics, political philosophy, metaphysics, epistemology, logic, and aesthetics. The philosophy major provides an excellent foundation for a wide array of career paths, including law, government, education, journalism, public policy, and business.

A minor in philosophy consists of 18 units approved by the department. Nine of these units must be upper-division. At least nine of the 18 units must be completed in residence. No course taken for the minor may be taken CR/NC. All courses must be completed with a grade of C- or higher. Only three units of PHIL 301, PHIL 302, or PHIL 303 may be counted toward the minor. Not more than three units of PHIL 340I, PHIL 341I, or PHIL 342I may be counted toward the minor. No more than six units of transfer credit may be applied to the minor.

The Minor in Photographic Studies is designed to provide students from any major with an understanding of the history, theory, and practice of photography. The minor provides opportunities for students to develop a body of work and a professional portfolio. Students who pursue the minor will develop visual literacy, critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills applicable to many fields. The minor may be especially useful for students in the arts and humanities, journalism, marketing, and business.

The Kinesiology (Physical Education) minor is for students interested in developing an understanding of physical education content, pedagogy, and issues associated with teaching physical education in K-12 settings. This minor is for students pursuing a bachelor's degree in any major and may be particularly appealing to students who are also interested in pursuing a single subject teaching credential in physical education.

The Department of Physics provides an education in the principles of physics and their application. It prepares students for a variety of careers in science, engineering, computing, and teaching, as well as for further study in graduate school. Physics majors develop skills in critical thinking, analytical reasoning, and quantitative problem-solving. Students complete a common core of courses that provide a strong background in classical mechanics, electricity and magnetism, quantum mechanics, thermal physics, mathematical methods in physics, and experimental techniques. Most physics courses integrate both theory and applications, and many include a hands-on laboratory component. All of our faculty teach both lecture and laboratory courses and engage undergraduates in research projects.

The Minor in Physics is an excellent option for any student with an interest in physics. It can provide a strong analytical background to support many science, engineering, and mathematics majors. This minor requires 18 units of coursework, with a minimum of six units completed at Chico State. Students must earn a minimum grade of C- in all courses used to satisfy the minor requirements, and an overall GPA of 2.0 in all courses attempted for the minor. Please consult with the Physics Department for minor advising.

Planning and development encompasses the analysis of physical, economic, and social factors that shape human settlements and their surrounding environments. It focuses on processes that produce sustainable, resilient, and equitable places. This minor is an introduction to the interdisciplinary field of planning for students in other majors who want to broaden their understanding of planning and development or who are considering careers in planning-related fields. The minor may be of particular interest to students in the social sciences, humanities, or environmental sciences.

The Plant and Soil Science program offers students a broad-based education in plant and soil science with options for specialization in particular areas of interest. Our curriculum integrates field, lab, and classroom learning with hands-on application and community engagement. Our facilities include greenhouses, teaching and research plots, and soil, water, and plant analytical laboratories. Chico State has been approved by the California Department of Food and Agriculture to offer the Pest Control Advisor (PCA) license for graduates of the Crop Production and Horticulture option. Chico State is also an accredited institution and offers students the option of completing a teaching credential in Agricultural Science and Education to teach at the secondary level. This option meets the requirements for the Agricultural Specialist Credential.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Plant and Soil Science

description: Political science is the systematic study of government, public policy, political processes, and political behavior. It aims to develop critical thinking skills necessary for understanding and participating in politics and public life. Political science includes the study of American government, international relations, comparative government, political theory, public law, public administration, and other aspects of political activity. The department helps students hone their abilities in written and oral communication, critical thinking, and political analysis. The curriculum is designed to provide students with a broad and balanced understanding of the field while allowing them to develop a deeper knowledge in areas of their interest. Additionally, students may choose to pursue an option in International Relations, Legal Studies, or Public Administration, which offer focused curricula within these areas.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Political Science

description: The Political Science minor is designed for students seeking to deepen their understanding of political institutions, processes, and theories without pursuing a full major. It provides a flexible yet rigorous curriculum that introduces students to various subfields within political science, including American politics, comparative politics, international relations, and political theory. Students will develop critical thinking, analytical, and research skills applicable to a wide range of careers and further academic study. This minor complements a variety of majors by offering insights into governance, policy-making, and global affairs.

Project management skills are in high demand in a wide range of industries and fields. The Minor in Project Management provides students with foundational knowledge and skills in project planning, execution, monitoring, control, and closeout. Students learn how to manage project scope, schedule, budget, resources, risk, and quality, and to communicate effectively with stakeholders. The minor is designed to complement any major, providing students with a valuable credential that enhances their career prospects in project-based environments.

The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Psychology provides students with a broad understanding of the scientific study of behavior and mental processes. The program emphasizes critical thinking, research methods, and ethical considerations in psychology. Students will develop a strong foundation in various areas of psychology, including cognitive, developmental, social, and abnormal psychology. The curriculum prepares students for entry-level positions in fields such as human services, education, and business, as well as for graduate studies in psychology or related disciplines. Graduates will be able to apply psychological principles to understand and address real-world problems, communicate effectively, and conduct basic research.

Public Administration is the study of how government and nonprofit organizations work. The program in Public Administration provides students with knowledge and skills to lead and manage in the public and nonprofit sectors. The BA in Public Administration prepares students for careers in public service, including local, state, federal, and international government, and in nonprofit organizations. The curriculum provides students with a strong foundation in political science, economics, and public policy, as well as specialized knowledge in public management, budgeting, and human resources. The program also emphasizes the development of critical thinking, communication, and leadership skills. Public administration professionals work to improve the quality of life for all citizens by addressing complex societal challenges such as poverty, inequality, environmental degradation, and public health crises. They play a vital role in shaping public policy, implementing programs, and delivering essential services to communities. With a degree in public administration, students can pursue a wide range of career opportunities, including urban planning, policy analysis, program management, human resource management, financial management, and nonprofit leadership. The program also prepares students for graduate study in public administration, law, or related fields.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Public Administration

description: The Public Administration Minor provides students with knowledge about administrative processes and organizations within governmental and nonprofit settings. Students interested in working in government and nonprofit organizations at any level will benefit from a minor in Public Administration. Students majoring in a variety of fields such as political science, criminal justice, sociology, liberal studies, business, health and community services, and agriculture are encouraged to consider a minor in public administration. The Public Administration Minor helps prepare students for entry-level positions in governmental and nonprofit organizations.

Public health is the science and art of preventing disease, prolonging life, and promoting health through organized community efforts. Public Health professionals work to protect and improve the health of individuals, families, communities, and populations locally and globally. They work to identify health needs, prevent the spread of disease, respond to public health emergencies, develop health education programs, enforce health policies, and assure access to healthcare. The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Public Health prepares students to apply social and behavioral sciences, environmental sciences, and biological sciences to analyze, develop, and implement public health interventions. This includes promoting individual health behaviors, ensuring the health of the environment, and developing and implementing sound health policy to ensure population health. Graduates are prepared for careers in government, non-profit, or private sector organizations. They are also well prepared for graduate studies in public health or other health-related fields. Specific career opportunities include: health educator, health advocate, community health worker, environmental health specialist, and public health policy analyst. Graduates also meet prerequisites for further study in health professions programs such as nursing, physical therapy, occupational therapy, and medicine.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Public Health

description: Public health is the science and art of preventing disease, prolonging life, and promoting health through the organized efforts and informed choices of society, organizations, communities, and individuals. The Public Health minor provides students with the opportunity to develop foundational knowledge and skills in public health. Through a multidisciplinary approach, students learn about the core functions of public Health, including assessment, policy development, and assurance. The minor introduces students to key areas such as epidemiology, environmental health, social and behavioral sciences, health policy and management, and biostatistics. This minor is suitable for students from various majors who wish to understand the broader context of health and disease, and how to promote well-being at a population level. It prepares students for entry-level positions in public health settings or for further graduate studies in public health and related fields.

The Queer and Trans Studies (QTS) Minor introduces students to the academic field of queer and trans studies, which explores critical approaches to gender and sexuality, emphasizing the experiences and intellectual contributions of LGBTQIA2S+ people and communities. The interdisciplinary minor draws from fields such as English, Communication, Multicultural and Gender Studies, Political Science, Psychology, and Sociology, inviting students to engage with diverse perspectives and methodologies. Students in the QTS Minor will develop a foundational understanding of queer and trans theories, histories, and contemporary issues. They will cultivate critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills applicable to various professional and civic contexts. The minor is designed to complement any major, providing students with a valuable lens for understanding identity, power, and social justice. Graduates with a QTS Minor will be prepared for careers in social justice advocacy, education, counseling, public service, and the arts, as well as for further academic study in related fields.
Program name: Minor in Queer and Trans Studies

description: The Minor in Race, Ethnicity, and Sovereignty (RES) GE is an interdisciplinary minor designed to provide students with a foundational understanding of race, ethnicity, and sovereignty as social and political constructs rooted in historical and ongoing global processes. The minor explores the intersections of race, ethnicity, and sovereignty through a critical lens, examining how these concepts shape identities, power relations, and social justice movements. This minor will foster critical thinking, analytical skills, and a global perspective, preparing students to engage with complex issues of diversity, equity, inclusion, and sovereignty in their academic, professional, and civic lives.
Program name: Minor in Race, Ethnicity, and Sovereignty GE

description: The Bachelor of Science in Recreation, Hospitality, and Parks Management (RHPM) degree is an interdisciplinary program preparing students for careers in the growing fields of recreation, hospitality, and park and natural resource management. With an emphasis on hands-on learning, service learning, and community engagement, students gain the practical skills and theoretical knowledge necessary to make a meaningful impact in the diverse industries of leisure and tourism. Through coursework in areas such as event planning, outdoor recreation, park operations, sustainable tourism, and hospitality management, students develop strong leadership, communication, and problem-solving abilities. The program emphasizes ethical practice, social responsibility, and cultural competence, ensuring graduates are well-prepared to lead and innovate in their chosen professions. Graduates are equipped to pursue a wide range of career opportunities in public, private, and non-profit sectors, including parks and recreation departments, hospitality venues, event management companies, outdoor adventure programs, and conservation organizations.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Recreation, Hospitality, and Parks Management

description: The Minor in Recreation, Hospitality, and Parks Management focuses on managing recreation, hospitality, and park services for the betterment of individuals, communities, and the environment. Through coursework and experiences, students develop knowledge and skills in designing and leading recreational activities, managing events and facilities, providing exceptional customer service, understanding the principles of sustainable tourism, and overseeing park operations. This minor prepares students for various roles in the rapidly growing leisure and tourism industries. These roles include event planners, recreation leaders, resort managers, park rangers, and tourism marketers. The minor complements a wide range of majors, including business, communication, environmental science, health, and sociology, by providing practical management skills applicable to diverse professional settings.
Program name: Minor in Recreation, Hospitality, and Parks Management

description: The Secondary Language Arts Minor is a supplemental minor for students in a single subject credential program, particularly those pursuing a credential in English. This minor focuses on developing an understanding of the diverse students who comprise secondary language arts classrooms (grades 7-12) as well as the unique challenges and opportunities that arise when teaching English learners, students with disabilities, and struggling readers and writers. This minor includes coursework in both the Department of English and the School of Education. It requires 21 units of coursework including a capstone course in which students must demonstrate proficiency with the California Common Core State Standards for English Language Arts (grades 7-12) and the California English Language Development Standards.

The Social Media Production and Analysis minor is designed to provide students from a wide range of majors with a broad understanding of social media systems, theories, and practices. Students will develop skills in the production and management of social media content and campaigns, as well as the analysis of social media data to inform strategic communication decisions. The minor will prepare students for careers in social media management, digital marketing, data analysis, and content creation across various industries. It emphasizes a blend of theoretical knowledge and practical application, ensuring students are well-equipped to navigate the evolving landscape of social media.
Program name: Minor in Social Media Production and Analysis

description: The minor in social work allows students from other disciplines to supplement their major with an understanding of social welfare policies and services, human behavior in the social environment, and social work practice. It is designed to prepare students to work in professions that provide social services and/or to pursue graduate education in social work. It is particularly helpful to students in Child Development, Psychology, Criminal Justice, Sociology, Health Sciences, Liberal Studies, and Multicultural and Gender Studies.

Social work is a professional discipline concerned with helping individuals, families, groups, organizations, and communities improve their social functioning. Social work aims to address societal problems and promote social justice and human rights. The Bachelor of Arts in Social Work (BASW) is a professional degree that prepares students for generalist social work practice at the entry-level. The program's curriculum provides a broad base of knowledge about human behavior in the social environment, social welfare policy, social work practice methods, social work research, and field education. The program emphasizes critical thinking, ethical decision-making, diversity, and social justice. Graduates are prepared for employment in a variety of social service settings, including child welfare, mental health, substance abuse, aging, health care, and community organizations. The BASW program is accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE).
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE)
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Social Work

description: The minor in sociology requires a minimum of 19 units selected in consultation with a sociology advisor. A grade of C- or higher must be earned in all courses used to satisfy the minor requirements. Students who complete the Minor in Sociology will be able to: Articulate the major theoretical perspectives in sociology. Demonstrate knowledge of major concepts and areas of inquiry in sociology, including social inequality, social institutions, social change, and the self and society. Identify appropriate methodologies for sociological research, including research ethics, and evaluate sociological evidence. Apply sociological perspectives to address social problems.

The Bachelor of Arts in Spanish provides students with a broad and balanced program of study focused on developing advanced linguistic and cultural competence. Students completing this major are prepared for a variety of careers in fields such as business, communications, foreign service, education, government, law, social services, and for graduate study in Spanish and other fields. Students are encouraged to study abroad.

The Minor in Spanish offers a sequence of courses designed to give students proficiency in the Spanish language and familiarity with the literatures and cultures of the Spanish-speaking world. Students completing the minor will have a greater understanding and appreciation of Spanish-speaking peoples and their cultures, both in the United States and abroad. This minor is particularly valuable for students pursuing careers in the health and social services, education, business, international relations, and public administration. Students are advised to meet with a Spanish advisor as early as possible in their academic career to discuss course selection and sequencing specific to their goals.

This minor is designed for students interested in working with children and adults with disabilities. Students will develop foundational knowledge and skills related to characteristics of disabilities, inclusive educational practices, instructional strategies for diverse learners, and legal and ethical considerations in special education. The minor provides a valuable credential for those pursuing careers in education, human services, psychology, and other related fields, and offers a strong foundation for further study in special education. The minor does not lead to a teaching credential.

The Sport Performance minor is designed for students interested in developing the knowledge and skills necessary to improve human physical performance in sport and exercise settings. The minor is appropriate for students pursuing a career in strength and conditioning, sports coaching, personal training, and graduate studies in exercise physiology, motor control, or biomechanics. Students will acquire foundational knowledge in exercise science, including biomechanics, exercise physiology, and strength and conditioning principles. They will also gain practical experience through hands-on activities and opportunities to apply their knowledge in real-world settings. The curriculum emphasizes evidence-based practices and critical thinking to prepare students for a dynamic field.

The Minor in Sports Media prepares students with a foundational understanding of the theories, principles, and applications of sport communication, including sport journalism, sport public relations, and sport broadcasting. The minor provides an interdisciplinary approach to sports media by drawing from courses in Communication, Journalism and Public Relations, and Kinesiology. This minor is intended for students who are interested in pursuing careers related to sports media.

The Minor in Statistics helps students develop a foundational understanding of probability and statistical inference, and computational skills necessary to analyze data. Students will learn how to apply statistical methods and interpret results, and how to effectively communicate these results in both oral and written forms. The minor provides an excellent supplement for students in a variety of fields, including biological sciences, business, economics, engineering, health sciences, and social sciences.

This minor provides students with the opportunity to deepen their understanding of sustainability and resilience principles while satisfying nine units of their General Education (GE) requirements. Students will take courses that analyze global and local sustainability challenges related to environmental, social, and economic systems. The minor will help students develop skills to understand and identify solutions to these complex problems across a variety of disciplines and contexts. Students will learn about topics such as climate change, resource management, social equity, and sustainable development. The minor is designed for students from all majors who want to incorporate sustainability and resilience into their academic and professional paths. The minor may be taken as a stand-alone minor or in conjunction with the Sustainability Certificate or the MS in Environmental Science.
Program name: Minor in Sustainability and Resilience GE

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Theatre Arts provides students with a broad and rigorous liberal arts education focusing on the study of theatre. Students are prepared for a variety of pursuits after graduation, including graduate study in theatre, arts administration, teaching, and professional theatre work. Students develop skills in critical thinking, writing, analysis, research, and performance that are applicable to a wide range of careers.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Theatre Arts

description: The minor in Theatre Arts provides students with an opportunity to explore the history, theory, and practice of theatre. Students are introduced to the history of theatre, learn about dramatic literature and criticism, and explore the areas of acting, directing, design, stagecraft, and playwriting. Through course work and productions, students develop an understanding and appreciation of theatre as a collaborative art form. The minor provides an excellent supplement to a wide range of majors, including English, communication, art, music, education, and business.

The Minor in Tourism provides students with an overview of the growing tourism industry. Students are provided with insight into the multi-faceted nature of the tourism industry, its cultural, economic, and political impacts, and issues related to global tourism. The Minor in Tourism exposes students to the various aspects of the tourism industry including, but not limited to, destination development, tourism marketing and management, cultural tourism, eco-tourism, and sustainable tourism. A minor in tourism can be an excellent complement to majors in Business, Communication, Anthropology, Geography, Recreation Hospitality and Parks Management (RHPM), and other areas that connect with the global nature of tourism.

The Minor in Video Game Design is an interdisciplinary minor designed to provide students with foundational skills in game design, digital media, art, and computer science. This minor allows students to pursue their interests in the field of video game design and development and prepares them to potentially pursue further studies or careers in this growing industry.

The Women's Studies minor brings together courses from a wide range of departments across campus to provide students with a deeper understanding of women's experiences and perspectives. Drawing from disciplines in the humanities, social sciences, and natural sciences, the minor fosters critical thinking about gender, power, and social justice. Students completing the minor will develop an intersectional understanding of women's and gender issues, preparing them for a variety of careers and for engaged citizenship in a diverse global society.
